info.game_comments: (Cheryl: Almost 60 years after she was launched, she's getting a well-deserved rest.  Clues from the battleship Missouri coming up on Jeopardy!)

(1, 1).clue: This "sea" has heavy mineral deposits which make it saltier than the oceans & almost uninhabitable

(2, 1).clue: The final vote count in this state in 2000 was Gore: 2,912,253,Bush: 2,912,790

(3, 1).clue: Kitty loves this 1972 Elton John song that says, "Well, I quit those days and my redneck ways"

(4, 1).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew reports from the U.S.S. Missouri in Hawaii.)  During the Gulf War in 1991, the U.S.S. Missouri fired its 16-inch guns in anger for the first time since this 1950s conflict

(5, 1).clue: At the A&W restaurants, order your burgers with a frosty mug of this beverage that they're famous for

(6, 1).clue: A Cricetus cricetus with large cheek pouches

(1, 2).clue: This Chinese river, Huang He, carries tons of colorful silt

(2, 2).clue: The top 2 Canadian newspapers in circulation are based in this city

(3, 2).clue: Naturally, "Cat People (Putting Out Fire)" is Kitty's favorite track on his album "Let's Dance"

(4, 2).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reports from the deck of the U.S.S. Missouri in Hawaii.)  On September 2, 1945, World War II ended when representatives of Japan surrendered right here to this commanding American general

(5, 2).clue: In TV commercials 'N Sync sings the praises of this chain's baby back ribs

(6, 2).clue: This tendon is at the back of the thigh

(1, 3).clue: This island was named for its location between the U.S. west coast & Japan

(2, 3).clue: Alexander Global Promotions is the biggest maker of these nodding dolls; it can make over 1 million a month

(3, 3).clue: Kitty just swoons when she hears Tom Jones sing this title movie tune

(4, 3).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew stands in front of the U.S.S. Missouri in Hawaii.)  It's the appropriate 2-word name for the predominate color of the U.S.S. Missouri

(5, 3).clue: Arnold Schwarzenegger & Bruce Willis were among the founders of this theme restaurant

(6, 3).clue: This man co-wrote several popular musicals including "The King and I"

(1, 4).clue: Captain Cook stayed on this island, later used for nuclear testing, December 25, 1777

(2, 4).clue: He was the last of the 3 men who were king of England during 1066

(3, 4).clue: Your cat's least favorite song?  "Misty", because of the line "Look at me, I'm" this
(3, 4).correct response: as helpless as a kitten up a tree

(4, 4).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reads from on the deck of the U.S.S. Missouri in Hawaii.)  This admiral, nicknamed "Bull", walked the deck of the Missouri, his flagship, in the latter part of World War II

(5, 4).clue: At this famous NYC restaurant at 234 W. 44th Street, you can dine with the stars, or at least with their caricatures

(6, 4).clue: He wrote hard-boiled detective novels like "The Maltese Falcon" & "The Thin Man"

(1, 5).clue: What's now this African country was once the center of trade for elephant merchandise

(2, 5).clue: At a latitude of 0 degrees 13 minutes south, this capital is at an altitude of 9,222 feet

(3, 5).clue: Your cat is not superstitious -- he loves crossing paths with her 1990 No. 1 hit "Black Cat"

(5, 5).clue: At the Olive Garden, you might start off with this dish of chopped tomatoes, basil & olive oil on ciabatta toast

(6, 5).clue: This county in southern England borders the English Channel

(1, 1).clue: The Vikings named an ice-covered island this to lure settlers there

(3, 1).clue: Koeberlina spinosa is the "crucifixion" one of these, the type of object Jesus wore a crown of

(4, 1).clue: His financial channel could report on his $165,000 salary

(5, 1).clue: In 1979 a play based on his novel "Fahrenheit 451" was produced in Los Angeles

(6, 1).clue: Not whitened, like some flour & linen

(1, 2).clue: Since it's the largest city in Missouri, we wonder why it's not called Missouri City

(2, 2).clue: Once nicknamed "Stecchetto", the Stick, because she was so skinny, she's the beauty who married Carlo Ponti

(3, 2).clue: The bulbs of this plant named for a Greek youth who fell in love with his image can cause digestive upset & trembling

(4, 2).clue: Last name of Chicago's mayor, or how often he earns $465.75

(5, 2).clue: He's won 2 Nat'l Book Awards: for "Goodbye, Columbus" in 1960 & for "Sabbath's Theater" 35 years later

(6, 2).clue: This title of the film seen here is descriptive of one of its leading characters

(1, 3).clue: You'll find Limestone & Peat on Ireland but not the gems this nickname would imply

(2, 3).clue: She thanked her father Paul when she won a 1995 Oscar for her role in "Mighty Aphrodite"

(3, 3).clue: Flowers are considered "perfect" if they contain both of these reproductive organs

(4, 3).clue: With $103,056 from this city, Wellington Webb doesn't have to pay you Tuesday for one of its omelets today

(5, 3).clue: This French author's original surname was Balssa before his father changed it

(1, 4).clue: Rock Island is not on an island but a city on the Mississippi River in this state that borders Iowa

(2, 4).clue: She played Tina Turner on the big screen & Rosa Parks on TV

(3, 4).clue: 4 true cedar trees exist: they are native to Cyprus, the Atlas Mountains, the Himalayas & this Mideast country

(5, 4).clue: Her first novel was written in collaboration with another author using the joint pseudonym Jules Sand

(6, 4).clue: To zoologists, a goat, or a guanaco

(1, 5).clue: The city of El Centro in this state is actually on its southern border, near Mexicali

(2, 5).clue: She directed the 1920 silent film "Remodeling Her Husband", starring her sister Dorothy

(3, 5).clue: The Black-Eyed Susan is the state flower of this Atlantic coast state

(5, 5).clue: This Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist co-wrote the play "Dinner at Eight" with George S. Kaufman

(6, 5).clue: Famous (& rather insulting) adjective for England's King Ethelred II

(0, 0).clue: Over the end credits of "Confessions of a Dangerous Mind" she sings "There's No Business Like Show Business"
